conclusion: To solve the problem, I will analyze the motion of oil droplets in the Millikan oil-drop experiment. I will use the given equations and conditions to determine the proportionality constant k.

Initially, both droplets A and B fall with a uniform velocity v0 through a distance h1 in time t. The acceleration due to gravity is g, so the equation of motion is: v0^2 = 2g(h1 - h2)
After applying the voltage, droplet B moves upwards with a new velocity v1 through a distance h2 in the same time t. The equation of motion for B is: v1^2 = 2g(h2 - h1)
The air resistance is given by f = k m^(1/3) v.
For droplet B, the force due to air resistance is: f = k m0^(1/3) v1
The net force on droplet B is the difference between the weight and the air resistance: mg - k m0^(1/3) v1 = m0 g
Simplifying gives: k m0^(1/3) v1 = m0 g
Solving for k gives: k = g / v1
Using the relation v1^2 = 2g(h2 - h1), we find: v1 = sqrt(2g(h2 - h1))
Substitute v1 into the equation for k: k = g / sqrt(2g(h2 - h1))
Simplifying gives: k = g / sqrt(2g(h2 - h1)) = g / sqrt(2g(h2 - h1)) * sqrt(2g(h1 - h2)) / sqrt(2g(h1 - h2)) = g sqrt(2g(h1 - h2)) / 2g(h2 - h1) = sqrt(2g(h1 - h2)) / 2(h2 - h1)
